ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This helped me develop my close reading skills and strengthen my argumentative writing.

I developed my skills as a literary analyst, both in close reading and synthesizing arguments from other criticism. I also developed a more comprehensive view of American history through the literature we read.
I learned how to closely read some of our country's most classic novels--understanding hidden meanings, cultural biases and external influences.
This course developed my analytical skills for both prose and poetry. I found the selection of readings very interesting and varied.
Throughout this course, I learned how to read, analyze, and enjoy poetry, and utilized skills of comprehension to connect multiple different texts with different themes to one another.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: excellent reading material, lively classroom discussions

The readings of the course are a major strength as well as its small seminar format. A weakness that could be improved upon is the absence of intermediary grades between papers, such as paragraph-long analysis or something to maintain student engagement.

The rich material and wonderful professor were certainly the highlights. The works in the class range a broad period, but often have overlapping messages and themes which can be helpful in developing a deeper understanding of the dualities of American history. The professor is extremely passionate about this subject and is both driven to push each student as well as understanding of their varied experiences.

The course was taught very well and all of the reading selections were engaging and well thought out. I feel like the reading selections are probably the strongest part of this course. It could possibly be improved by offering more ways to interact with the material discussed in class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Flexibility with deadlines, small supportive classroom environment, homework/reading done offline
Small seminars are much better in the covid-zoom environment.

The ability to read physical things during this pandemic was a welcome escape. And our class discussions were well balanced and paced, even over zoom. I do not believe anything would need to be improved.
I believe this class worked well despite the pandemic. Since this class was a small seminar, I do not think that the format of the class changed very much with it being online.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Certainly! If a student has any interest at all in American Literature or American History, this course is perfect.

I would--especially those looking to build a well-rounded understanding of American history. The course raises challenging questions about the English language and American history (with the two occasionally overlapping), but it was invaluable in my college experience.

Yes. Especially if you are planning on becoming an English major, this class is a great class to take. It will teach you many of the skills you will need as you continue to take literature classes. If you are not an English major but you are still interested in literature, I would still recommend this class as it is very engaging and the seminar format allows you to engage with the material a lot more than in a lecture course.
I would recommend this course to another student because I enjoyed conversations with the instuctor and the structure of the class lent itself to very engaging conversations.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
